author: nishant0
content: Wonder if thats something we should be doing ? Restricting the peers entered into the routing table to have the same digest would solve our problem. But doesn't it go against the goal to have one global dht which has peers of varying protocols ? Eth2,eth1,etc

author: jonny.derp
content: Ya it definitely goes against the `global dht` goal, but i would categorize it as a workaround for phase0 until we have topic discovery.  Definitely open to other ideas

author: donschoe
content:
> Multiaddr and ENR are not directly comparable because they solve different problems
Exactly. So why can't we just use Multiaddr for bootnode records for example?

author: ajsutton
content: I could be wrong but I don't think you can convert a Multiaddr to the same details an ENR provides to connect to a bootnode in discv5.  discv5 requires the public key but the Multiaddr peer ID is a hash of the public key.

author: nishant0
content:
Yeap, I don't think it will work. Although we could use an enode url, like in eth1 currently . There are currently discv5 bootnodes running with `enode url` as their identitites 
https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/blob/master/params/bootnodes.go#L68

Are there any known downsides to connecting to bootnodes via this method ? it has the node id + ip + port, which is all is needed for a remote peer to initiate the connection.

author: donschoe
content: Ah, I didn't know it's just the hash of the pubkey.
